did.unittitle: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia artifacts.

bioghist.p: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia was founded in 1812 "for the encouragement and cultivation of the sciences, and the advancement of useful learning." Its collections, acquired through expeditions, gifts, purchases, and exchanges, contain over 17,000,000 specimens. The Academy opened its doors to the public in 1828, growing so rapidly that it outgrew its building three times in sixty years. In 1876, its present home was built at 19th and Benjamin Franklin Parkway. In 1948, with the establishment of the Environmental Research Division, the Academy broadened its research orientation to include applied research in aquatic ecosystems as well as the traditional systematics research--discovering and cataloguing organisms.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of artifacts associated with the Academy and its staff. Items include: printing blocks, seals, and signature stamps; dies for the Joseph Leidy medal; a plaster mold for the Academy's Gold Medal; three medals given to the Academy by other scientific institutions (1920-1922); a wooden ballot box from the American Entomological Society; exhibit signs and plaques; a plaster statuette of Edward J. Nolan; several scientific instruments, including 19th century British chronometer, a Mohs hardness scale set of minerals; Henry Pilsbry's black leather case; a large eiderdown robe; two rolled African animal batiks; commemorative caps and t-shirts; and a hardhat and apron used by Carol Spawn, the Academy's archivist. The collection also includes a set of Native American clothing and tools belonging to John James Audubon that were donated to the Academy by one of his descendants. The set includes a pair of trousers, a leather jacket, two sets of moccasins, a beaded blanket, a stone ax head, a knife scabbard, a set of bear claws, a beaded pouch, and a pelican silk robe.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
